climbs.name: Residence Inn
climbs.fa: Logan Tolley, Chance Mone, Tristan Mohs, March 7th 2019

content.description: The crux is getting up onto the first ledge. Feet are everything! Two pads are ideal and a spotter is a necessity because you do move horizontally during the climb with a rock and tree behind you.
content.location: The start hold is the solid quartz piece shown in images. From there, you climb up to the right onto a small ledge before fully topping out on the boulder. Follow general directions to Fox Den Boulder.

content.description: Underclings starting from a big piece of quartz about 3' off the ground. move feet out left and keep tension as you work through sidepulls and underclings. Solid rock all the way through, some sharp spots for sure. Lots of options for feet.
content.location:
Northern Bank of Dick Branch Little Gunpowder Falls. Access from Harford Road.

  Coordinates:39.4854051,-76.4316209

  follow the waterfall trail across the stream and look up the hill, there is a game trail starting downstream that is pretty easy to use to get there

content.description:
Sit start on left-facing jugs, 3 feet right of Rabbit's Foot. Work straight up through more left facing holds before pulling into the groove directly above. Top out using cryptic holds on either side of groove and commitment.

 Mossy - grade might come down after a thorough cleaning and refined beta.

Sit start on shallow jug low and left of large quartz block of Residence Inn. Pull into quartz and then head up and left to left-facing groove directly above.  Pull over bulge to gain quartz knobs to top out.

 Mossy - a good cleaning may uncover easier beta I missed.

Beautiful wavy rock with vertical bands perpendicular to the ground. Looks chossy but very solid, chock full of crystals cracks and underclings. Fairly high above the river, plenty of space for crashpads and hanging out. Try to clean the top out, dirt and leaf litter settle on the very top of the route. Bring multiple crashpads. Named after apparent den nestled underneath the left corner of the rock.
